articles.description: In order to avoid any kind of transmission of the novel Coronavirus through air conditioners, the Indian Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air Conditioning Engineers (ISHRAE) has released some guidelines for household as well as public sector outlets.

articles.title: Over 6.65 lakh samples tested so far: Data from south states, Maharashtra - The News Minute
articles.description: India has ramped up testing since the 21-day lockdown was announced on March 24, which has now been extended to May 3.  According to the Indian Council of Medical Research, a total of 6,65,819 samples have been tested till April 27, 9 am. No further data was …

articles.title: Andhra Pradesh develops app to monitor paracetamol buyers - Bangalore Mirror
articles.description: Andhra Pradesh has developed an app to monitor the people coming to medical shops for over-the-counter drugs for cough, cold and breathing problems. ​

articles.author: Sophie Harris
articles.title: Pollen count: Four ways to manage your hay fever symptoms when the count is high - Express
articles.description: HAY FEVER is an allergic reaction and many Britons suffer with it every year. Allergies may be worse when the pollen count is high. There is no cure for hay fever but there are many ways to help manage and treat the symptoms.

articles.author: Adam Minter
articles.title: Why children may be the silent victims of coronavirus - ThePrint
articles.description: The most consequential effects of this Covid crisis for children are likely to come from two areas: Health and education.
articles.content:
Many parents felt a profound sense of relief when analyses of the coronavirus found that kids rarely show symptoms and usually arent at much risk. Unfortunately, that doesn’t mean theyre safe from the global pandemic.
Every parent is familiar with the day-to… [+4764 chars]

articles.author: Julie Zaugg, for CNN
articles.title: The virus hunters who search bat caves to predict the next pandemic - CNN
articles.description: Before entering the cave, the small team of scientists pull on hazmat suits, face masks and thick gloves to cover every inch of their skin. Contact with bat droppings or urine could expose them to some of the world's deadliest unknown viruses.
